claim: The Great Gatsby was inspired by the novel 1984.

supporting.text: The Great Gatsby was published in 1925, while 1984 was published in 1949, making it impossible for the former to be inspired by the latter.

attacks.text: The Great Gatsby was published in 1925, while 1984 was published in 1949, making it impossible for the former to be inspired by the latter.
Literary influence can sometimes be posthumous or through unpublished drafts, so earlier works could theoretically be inspired by later ones if the authors interacted or shared ideas.
There is no historical evidence of any interaction or shared ideas between F. Scott Fitzgerald and George Orwell that would support such an unusual influence.

supporting.text: F. Scott Fitzgerald, the author of The Great Gatsby, died in 1940, before George Orwell even began writing 1984.

attacks.text: F. Scott Fitzgerald, the author of The Great Gatsby, died in 1940, before George Orwell even began writing 1984.
Literary influence can occur posthumously through unpublished notes or ideas shared with other writers.
There is no documented evidence that Fitzgerald's unpublished works or ideas influenced Orwell's 1984.
The Great Gatsby and 1984 share thematic similarities, such as critiques of societal structures, suggesting possible indirect influence.
Thematic similarities between works do not necessarily indicate direct inspiration, as many authors independently explore common societal issues.

supporting.text: The themes and settings of The Great Gatsby (American Jazz Age) and 1984 (dystopian totalitarianism) are fundamentally different and unrelated.

attacks.text: The themes and settings of The Great Gatsby (American Jazz Age) and 1984 (dystopian totalitarianism) are fundamentally different and unrelated.
While themes differ, both novels critique societal structures, suggesting possible indirect influence.
There is no documented evidence or historical record of F. Scott Fitzgerald being influenced by George Orwell's work.
Literary influence can exist without thematic similarity, through stylistic or narrative techniques.
The Great Gatsby was published in 1925, while 1984 was published in 1949, making direct influence impossible.

supporting.text: There is no historical evidence or documented correspondence suggesting Fitzgerald was aware of or influenced by Orwell's work.

attacks.text: There is no historical evidence or documented correspondence suggesting Fitzgerald was aware of or influenced by Orwell's work.
Fitzgerald and Orwell were contemporaries, and literary influences can occur without direct documentation.
The lack of documented evidence makes such influence highly speculative and unlikely to be provable.
Thematic similarities between the two works could suggest indirect influence or shared cultural concerns.
Thematic overlaps are common in literature and do not necessarily indicate direct inspiration.
